title: Protocol to isolate human normal and neoplastic pancreatic cells for single-cell omic analyses
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
      Normal and neoplastic human pancreatic tissue harvesting
    
Timing: 20 min
        Cut away a piece of pancreatic tissue by a qualified pathologist (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2869-Fig1.jpg
              Figure 1. Harvesting and processing of normal pancreatic tissue
            
              (A) The normal pancreas is harvested during pancreatic surgeries.
            
              (B) Fascia, fats, and necrotic and scorched parts are removed
              carefully from the tissue.
            
        Remove any blood, fascia, necrotic of scorched areas from the tissue.
      
Note: A tissue size of 15 mm × 15 mm×5 mm
      generates a single-cell suspension of 100 μL with 1000/μL live cells (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
    
        Place the tissue in approximately 10 mL of Preservation Buffer in a
        50-mL tube and transport it on ice to the laboratory within 30 min.
      
Tissue dissection
Timing: 5 min
        Transfer the tissue to a 50-mL tube and add approximately 10 mL of cold
        1×PBS. Gently invert the tube several times.
      
Critical: Repeat step 4 twice to wash
      off any residual blood and pancreatic enzymes released on the tissue’s
      surface.
    
        Transfer the tissue to a 5-mL conical tube and add approximately 1 mL of
        Digestion Buffer (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2869-Fig2.jpg
              Figure 2. Schema for pancreatic tissue dissection
            
              (A) Processed tissue is placed in a tube perfused with 1 mL
              digestion buffer.
            
(B) The tissue is minced with a scissor into a paste mixture.
(C) The mixture is transferred to a round dish.
              (D) The mixture is resuspended with digestion buffer until the
              total volume is 10 mL.
            
        Using sterile ophthalmic straight scissor, mince the tissue on ice into
        tiny pieces smaller than 1 mm × 1 mm within 5 min (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
      
        For normal human pancreas, transfer the mixture to a 100 mm × 20 mm

round culture dish using a sterile Pasteur pipette (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C). Add enough Digestion Buffer to reach a maximum volume of 10 mL (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D). For neoplastic human pancreas, transfer the mixture to a 50-mL tube
        and add enough Digestion Buffer to reach a maximum volume of 15 mL.
      
Note: There are no significant differences
      in the types of cells detected from normal and neoplastic pancreas,
      referring to Peng et al. (2019).1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Tissue dissociation
      The process for dissociating normal pancreatic tissue differs from that
      for neoplastic pancreatic tissue dissociation, so the steps are described
      separately.
    
To dissociate normal pancreatic tissue
Timing: 15 min
        Incubate the mixture in a 100 mm × 20 mm round culture dish at 37°C for
        5 min in a constant temperature
        
C O
2
        incubator.
      
        Pipette the mixture gently about 20 times, and incubate the mixture at
        37°C for another 5 min.
      
Critical: Before each new incubation,
      a microscopic examination to evaluate the tissue’s dissociation state is
      necessary (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
    
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2869-Fig3.jpg
          Figure 3. Microscopic examination of stepwise tissue dissociation
        
          (A) tissue state after the first round of dissociation, with few cell
          clusters detached from major tissues.
        
          (B–D) tissue state after the second to fourth round of dissociation,
          with more cell clusters dissociated from major tissues. Scale bar:
          50 μm.
        
        After incubation, transfer the mixture to a new 50-mL tube and let it
        stand for 30 s until tissue pieces settle down. Then, filter the
        supernatant through a 40-μm strainer into another tube. (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2869-Fig4.jpg
              Figure 4. Schema for cell suspension harvesting
            
              (A) The dissociated mixture is transferred into a 50-mL tube and
              allowed to stand still until all tissue pieces settle down.
            
              (B) The supernatant is transferred from the old tube (tube i) into

a new tube (tube ii) and the sediment proceeds with next round of
              dissociation.
            
              (C) The supernatant is filtrated with a 40-μm strainer and visible
              un-dissociated tissues remain.
            
        Resuspend the sediment with 10 mL Digestion Buffer, transfer the mixture
        into a new 100 mm × 20 mm round culture dish for another round of Steps
        8–10 until the fourth time.
      
Critical: Process each supernatant
      from every round of tissue dissociation in the Cell purification part
      separately, as it is critical for high cell viability.
    
To dissociate neoplastic pancreatic tissue
Timing: 1 h
        Incubate the mixture in a 50-mL tube at 37°C for 5 min at a shaking
        speed of 50 r.p.m.
      
        Using a clean Pasteur pipette, pipette the mixture gently for about 20
        times, and incubate for another 5 min under the same conditions as Step
        12.
      
Critical: Practically, after the first
      5 min of incubation, the minced tissue will form a viscous mass suspending
      in the Digestion Buffer, pipette gently in Step 13 to disperse the mass,
      and facilitate further dissociation. Pipette again in Step 14 to reinforce
      the effect (see Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5] and
      troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
    
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2869-Fig5.jpg
          Figure 5. Schema for neoplastic pancreas dissociation
        
          (A) The minced tissue in a viscous mass form will restrict further
          dissociation.
        
          (B) The tissue is resuspended after pipetting with a Pasteur pipette.
        
        Pipette the mixture gently for about 20 times, and continue incubation
        for 20 min in the same condition of Step 12.
      
        After incubation, gently pipette the solution, and then let it stand for
        30 s until most tissue pieces settle down before continuing with the
        next step.
      
        Filter the supernatant through a 40-μm strainer, keep the filtrate on
        ice.
      
        Resuspend the sediment with 15 mL Digestion Buffer and continue

incubating the mixture at 37°C for 30 min at a shaking speed of 50
        r.p.m.
      
After incubation, filter the mixture through a 40-μm strainer.
Collect the filtrates from Step 16 and Step 18.
Cell purification
Timing: 30 min
      Purification improves sample purity and viability, by removing red blood
      cells, cell debris and other impurities, and further singularizes cells by
      intermittent gentle pipette. For single-cell omics, Cell purification
      eliminates the DNase I in the final single cell suspension, ensuring the
      subsequent library construction.
    
Centrifuge the filtrate at 800 × g for 4 min at 4°C.
        Discard the supernatant, resuspend the pellet in at least 5 mL freshly
        prepared Lysis Buffer and incubate at room temperature for 5 min,
        avoiding light.
      
Critical: Make sure the 1×RBC lysis
      buffer is kept on ice and the DNase I is not added to the buffer until
      Step 21.
    
Critical: It is important to resuspend
      the pellet completely and filter the suspension through a 40-μm strainer
      to remove the minute impurities.
    
        Transfer the suspension into a 15-mL tube, centrifuge it at 800 × g
        for 4 min at 4°C (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] and
        troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2869-Fig6.jpg
              Figure 6. Comparison of the pellet before and after the RBC lysis
              step
            
              (A) The pellet before the RBC lysis step appears with visible red
              part.
            
(B) The pellet shows the satisfying result of RBC lysis.
        Discard the supernatant, resuspend the pellet with 1 mL Wash Buffer with
        the wide-bore pipette tips, transfer it into a new 15-mL tube, add
        excess 4 mL Wash Buffer.
      
Centrifuge the suspension at 600 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Critical: It is critical to transfer
      the suspension into a new clean tube before centrifugation to prevent low
      cell yield caused by tiny invisible impurities adhering to the tube wall
      during subsequent steps.

Discard the supernatant, resuspend the pellet with 1 mL Wash Buffer with
        the wide-bore pipette tips, transfer it into a new 15-mL tube, add
        excess 4 mL Wash Buffer (see
        troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
      
Centrifuge the suspension at 400 × g for 6 min at 4°C.
Note: Steps 23–26 are flexible washing
      steps designed to remove impurities, digestion enzymes, and Dnase I.
      Adjusting the centrifugation speed and time can help wash off impurities
      smaller than cells, avoiding excessive cell loss. If necessary, an
      additional washing step can be performed to remove any remaining
      impurities.
    
        Resuspend the pellet with an appropriate volume (40–200 μL) of Wash
        Buffer with the wide-bore pipette tips.
      
Pause point: The resuspended cell
      sample can be kept on ice for up to an hour.
    
Note: The volume of Wash Buffer varies
      according to the subsequent experiments. For single cell sequencing based
      on 10× Genomics platform, 100 μL cell suspension with 1000 cells/μL would
      be adequate.
    
        Mix 10 μL of the suspension with 10 μL of 0.4% Trypan blue stain and
        assess the viability and concentration of cells by Countess II and
        microscopy (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7] and
        troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2869-Fig7.jpg
              Figure 7. Examination of cell viability by Countess Ⅱ and
              microscope
            
              (A) Microscopic examination of 0.4% Trypan blue dyed cell
              suspension, (imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2869-Fx5.jpg) shows dead cell stained with 0.4% Trypan blue, (imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2869-Fx6.jpg) shows live cell without 0.4% Trypan blue staining. Scale bar:
              100 μm.
            
              (B) Countess Ⅱ examination shows 1.15×107/mL
              concentration and 90% cell viability.
            
        For single-cell suspension, dilute the suspension to required
        concentration by adding an appropriate volume of Wash Buffer based on
        the initial cell concentration.
